generalfeedback.text:
Worked Solution

To find the derivative of the function \( f(x) = \left(x^4 + {@aa@}x^3 + {@bb@}x + {@dd@}\right)^{@ee@} \) we wish to apply the chain rule.


Firstly, we identify the inner function and determine its derivative.

We will write the inner function as \( g(x) = x^4 + {@aa@}x^3 + {@bb@}x + {@dd@} \).
To find its derivative, we apply the power rule and the addition rule.

\(\begin{align*} g'(x) &= \textstyle \frac{d}{dx} \left( {@inside@} \right) \\ &= \textstyle \frac{d}{dx} \left(x^4\right) + \frac{d}{dx} \left({@aa@}x^3\right) + \frac{d}{dx} \left({@bb@}x\right) + \frac{d}{dx} \left({@dd@}\right) \\ &= {@dinside@} \end{align*}\)


We can now apply the chain rule.

\(\begin{align*} f'(x) &= \textstyle \frac{d}{dx} \left(g(x)\right)^{@ee@} \\ &= {@ee@} \left( g(x) \right)^{@(ee - 1)@} \cdot g'(x) \\ &= {@ee@} \left( {@inside@} \right)^{@(ee - 1)@} \left(4x^3 + {@ 3*aa@}x^2 + {@bb@}\right) \end{align*}\)

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.
